generalInfo:
Oh this exclusive 14-day tour we take you on experiential adventure so you can enjoy local markets, mosques, high tea by the Lake in Chitral, forts, castles and caves.

On this trip not only do you see and enjoy Islamabad and Lahore, but we also take you on a taste journey to enjoy local street food. Visit Chitral, home to the Kalasha Valleys and the Kalash people, as well as the Hindukush Valley and historic city of Peshawar.

You will get to see the handicraft the local women in Kalash do, see the art of making Chappli Kebabs in Peshawar from scratch, enjoy local street food, visit the Wagha Border which is the dividing line between India and Pakistan and has a daily ceremony of the hoisting of the flag, it can only be compared with changing of the guards at Buckingham Palace, although the atmosphere is significantly more electric with a great light hearted rivalry of cheers between the Indian and Pakistani crowds.

This tour has the perfect mix of natural beauty, people, culture, food and local shopping all created and developed with the local community so you can immerse yourself in the culture of Pakistan and the local community can benefit directly.

The festivals in Kalash take place on the following dates in 2025;

Chilam Joshi Festival - 13th - 16th May;
Uchal Festival 20th - 22nd August;
Choimus Festical - 15th - 22nd December

If you would like to join any of these festivals we can plan the itinerary around these dates.

dayInfo.description: Based on arrival on the previous night. Breakfast at Margalla Hills, followed by a city tour which includes visiting Faisal Mosque & Pakistan Monument.On arrival at the Islamabad you will be meet by the guide or driver and taken to the hotel for check in (Hotel Check In time is 14:00 hours). After a brief stop to freshen up at the hotel, you will begin the tour of Islamabad city. Islamabad was designed by the famous Greek architect Doxiades in the early 1960’s at the edge of the Potohar plateau. The city is divided into eight zones, including an administrative sector, diplomatic enclave, residential areas, educational sectors, industrial sectors, commercial areas, and rural and green areas. The city is known for the presence of several parks and forests, including the Margalla hills and Shakarparian park, we begin our tour at Shakerparian (or Sweet Hills) Park from where we will get a bird’s eye view of Islamabad. Nearby is the Pakistan Monument which is inspired by Moghul architecture, and has four petal-like structures symbolizing the four main cultures of the country, a small museum narrating the history and creation of Pakistan, both of which are connected by a small plaza known as the Freedom Plaza. Dinner at Monal to get a panoramic view of the city of Islamabad Overnight at Hotel.

Leave Islamabad after breakfast, making your way to Swat, also known as Switzerland of Asia because of its blue lakes, lush green pine trees and snow-capped mountains. Once in Swat, you will visit the Swat museum & Buddh Kara. Overnight stay at hotel

The day will be spent mainly on the road driving to the Kailash valley, as you drive you will see the change in topography from lush green pines to more Rocky Mountains. The Kailash valley is based in the Hindukush, one of the valleys which has been impacted by the Climate change & was visited by Prince William & Kate in 2020. Overnight at Hotel.

These two days you will spend in the valley taking part in the Uchal Festival. This is one of the top cultural festivals of Pakistan, the people of Kalash celebrate around 4 festivals during the course of the year. In the Uchal festival, the people pay homage to their God with food & crops, they prepare corn, buttermilk & cheese to celebrate the festival & rejoice uchao. Overnight at hotel.

Leave for Chitral after breakfast. After some rest at the hotel, you will be taken to visit the Shahi masjid & Chitral Bazaar. After lunch you will be taken to the Chitral Gol National Park to see the Markhor’s, the national animal of Pakistan, which come out at 5pm to go to the streams to get water. Overnight at hotel.

A day excursion to Gharam Chashma, known as the Hot Springs, will take place. However we are looking at changing this as reviews haven’t been great, so may change this to departure to Peshawar so you have an extra day in Peshawar.
Upon arrival in Peshawar, after some rest, you will be taken to explore the street food on offer in Qissa Khwani Bazaar.

The morning will take you to the visit the Sethi Mohalla, home to 7 of the most incredible pieces of architecture now protected as world heritage sites. Exploring the neighbouring clock tower & local shops which sell Afghani rugs, Peshawari Chappals a couple of items that Peshawar is famous for. After this you will depart and make your way to Taxila, on route to Islamabad. Taxila is home to the Mesolithic cave & archaeological remains of early settlement, made up of Buddhist monasteries. After this you will then go on for an overnight stay in Islamabad.

Following an early breakfast, you will leave and make your way to Rohtas Fort before going to the Wagha Border where you will enjoy the light-hearted ceremony of Pakistan’s equivalent of changing of the guards. It is a light-hearted affair with a lovely patriotic vibe on both sides India & Pakistan. Rohtas Fort is another UNESCO World heritage site, built by Sher Shah Suri. It is an exceptional example of early Muslim military architecture in Central & South Asia.

The day will comprise of a visit of many of the famous key sites made up of the Walled City of Lahore, which includes Lahore Fort & Badhshai mosque, followed by dinner at the famous Haveli restaurant, which is a lovely view overlooking the Badshahi mosque.

This will be a relaxing day, at which you can visit the local markets of Gulberg of which Anarkali is one of them. In the evening a visit to the famous Poet restaurant will be arranged which is an experience in itself. https://poetrestaurant.com/

Leave Lahore early for the drive back to Islamabad. Along the way a visit will be made to the famous Khewra Caves, 2nd largest salt mines in the world & the Katas Temple, where many Hindu’s still visit for an annual pilgrimage.
